FRIDAY, OCT. I, 1886.
THE PARTY PRESS.
While we do not believe in the party press being so many party slaves, who must do the bidding of a political party, they do, however, serve the cause of party government; but we cannot but regret that newspaper claiming to reflect the principles of our institutions and to appeal to them upon themselves to resurrect dead issues, and create national and religious strife, should be permitted to become the chief influences of party government. We have to deal with living issues. We have to deal with living issues and days gone by things were not just as they should have been; that is none of our business. Because such a state of affairs may have existed, there was a lack of good sense on the part of our forefathers; it is better now than then; we have to have a great deal more of common sense; to have a stronger faith in the common brotherhood of mankind; to be better Christians and better citizens; hence, we should see to it that we do not forfeit our right to consider our actions and our country's actions in place in the world within which there were so many conflicting interests as in the British North American Union. Confederation was required to be a cause for all these differences. Under every man has his own idea of what is religious or otherwise. Old bonds were settled, and the future could only be anticipated by those who had confidence in God. Does it not seem now impossible to the extreme, even criminal, to resurrect old bonds, dig up old skeletons from the political graveyard? We must look toward a new life, as is being done to-day by leading journals of both political parties and by many of our religious leaders. There is no excuse to say that because one journal is guilty of such an offence, another is justified in doing the same thing. We know George Brown said many very hard things about Orangemen and Catholics, and because he said them, the Orangeman, lodge, and like facts, should not be allowed to interfere with living national interests. Sir John Macdonald, at the Conservative banquet in London, Oct. 16th, showed why the most convincing manner can be dangerous, by the insinuation of race and religious issues upon the political arena. After dwelling at length on the difficulties of the situation as he referred to the press of the country, he said the Conservative press was independent, while the Liberal press was subservient. He endorsed this fact because he did not feel bound to be responsible for the views expressed in any press. If the press of Canada or Great Britain would only know for whom they work, they would be in a far better condition. His lordship declared that the difficulties of real life, external to those affecting Parliament, are far more pressing than those of a purely religious character. MOORE & MACDOWALL
Lorne Agricultural Society Dinner.

The 3rd Annual Exhibition of the Lorne Agricultural Society, consisting of which we will give a full report next week, and which we will conduct our series this week, was held at the dinner in the evening of fifty gentlemen members and friends of the society, who came down to the dinner in the Park Hotel. Previous to the supper the P.A.C. Band assisted at the dinner in transmitting their musical talent in the selection of music in their usual excellent manner.

After the gentlemen had made a very exhausted test of the different courses provided by the host, and pronounced them first class, dinner was served.

President Craig announced the intellectual part of the proceedings by proposing the usual loyal toast, which were received in the usual manner.

The next toast was the Lt.-Governor and Governor General, coupled with his name, the latter being the Governor in the latter terms to Lords Lorne, Dufferin, and Lansdowne, expressing it as his opinion that the present Governor Generals were all men, the latter possessing the brightest intellect of any man ever placed in such a position. It was considered an honor to have Governor General Macdonald a good man.

The Army and Navy was responded to by Capt. Henry, who considered the British troops the best in the world, except perhaps, the Canadian volunteers and the Royal Marines.

The Society Judges was responded to by Mr. Conners, of Carrot River, who said he thought the exhibition was only a farce. He was pleased to be present and nothing could be said for the Society, and that not the least credit was due the district.

Mr. Craig, vice-chairman, then proposed the North-West Council, coupled with the name of Mr. Hugh M.N.W.C., in doing so he referred in complimentary terms to Mr. Dewdney, and expressed his hope that the North-West Council would soon be succeeded by a Legislative Assembly.

Mr. Miller replied at length. Speaking of the School Board, he said the elected members had managed to have the money granted for school purposes by the Dominion government placed at the disposal of the members of the Council, and that was the reason schools had been opened in the district. He thought the elected members of the Council should have control of North-west schools, and should be representatives of the people. This was the first time he had returned thanks as an Agricultural chairman, and he hoped the North-West Council would be the last, but before another exhibition of the Society the Northwest would have a Legislative Assembly.

Mr. Craig next proposed Kindred Societies, coupled with the name of the Carrot River Agricultural Society. In doing so speaking of a visit he had paid to the Carrot River country some three years ago, he spoke of the very remarkable improvement he had seen.

Mr. Chas. Robertson, President of the Carrot River Agricultural Society, replied in behalf of that Society. He was afraid he would have to apologize, as he was not speaking for the Carrot River Agricultural Society. He thought the Kindred Societies the finest kind. What would Ontario be today without Agricultural Societies? They brought together their products together and was a means of improving stock. They thought they should have control of the Kindred Society was not in the same position as the Lorne Agricultural Society. It was carried on a grand scale, and striking along unaided. He was pleased to be present at the exhibition, and to notice the marked improvement. The time was not far distant when Prince Albert would have its Central station, and he hoped in that time, he hoped also to see the day when Prince Albert would be as large as Prince Albert was today.

Mr. Macdonald proposed the Masonic Institution, coupled with the names of Messrs. T. Agnew and J. Stewart. Mr. Stewart replied briefly, thanking Mr. Macdonald for his remarks, and in the way in which he had referred to the merchants. Referring to the agricultural interests, he said the merchants were sold without any consideration, and in view of the interests of the merchants to encourage agriculture.

Mr. Agnew then thanked these present for the way in which the toast was received. He thought the exhibition had been a success, and expressed his satisfaction that spectators should have been appointed to protect articles from being taken away, and hoped they would be appointed in future.

The Secretary made some explanation concerning the Society's losses, and explained his regret that Mr. H.B. cup had not been competed for, owing to the fact that the quantity of grapes purchased by Mr. McMillan was too few. Referring to Mr. McMillan, who was always a good friend of the Society, he said that gentleman had divided up into small prizes. He proposed the health of the donors of the prizes, and that was responded to by Messrs. Macdonald and Macleod, who returned thanks.

Mr. L. Macdonald, after expressing his pleasure at the successful exhibition and throwing off a few friendly hints to the directors, sang "Frans of Orders."

Mr. J. Stewart then proposed the health of the successful exhibitors, coupled with the names of Mr. Craig, Conners, Miller, and McMillan. In doing so he mentioned the fact that on his recent trip to Winnipeg he visited the fair, where he saw a number of which he had heard so much, and that Mr. McMillan and Mr. Riddell, and a number of others present by those gentlemen had won a sample of what was exhibited. He had also shown it to Com. Murray Smith, who was well pleased with it, and he was glad to send it to Ottawa. He thought this fact solved the problem as to whether wheat could be grown in the district.

Messrs. Thomson and Miller returned thanks.

The Town Council was proposed by Mr. McPhail and responded to by Mr. Conn Brown on behalf of the Council. Council presented a complimentary address, which was eloquently responded to by Mr. John Macdonald, who concluded by saying that he looked for Mr. Ogilvie for such a fine hotel as the Queen's, which were given.

The President next proposed the President of the Lorne Agricultural Society, that a few hitchcocks had occurred during the exhibition, and that some had acted improperly.

The Time-man, after having asked whether he was the culprit or not, and placing himself in retirement, took for the time being the place he was pleased with the exhibition. He had done all he could to make the exhibition a success, and hoped it would be full to give a full report of it.

The Ladies were represented by Mr. Conners, and Aborn Friends of Mr. Conners.

The health of the Secretary being drunk was responded to Mr. Clark at some length.

At this stage the proceedings were interrupted by an individual with an electric light, who gave a violent speech in his boast of the progress. He proceeded to say, but our reporter was asleep during the proceedings, and consequently was unable to thank the chairman and singing the National Anthem, the company broke up.

The latest despatches.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 29th.

No further particulars yet respecting Hudson's Bay Railway negotiations. It is generally reported that nothing has been decided beyond the question of joint government. Sutherland is expected to arrive here Friday morning.

Cravens, who has been engaged in the Winnipeg, took place today. The ceremony was performed by the Lt. Gov. and Judge McCann.

The Provincial Fair was opened on Wednesday by the Lieutenant-Governor, who was also made by members of the government, the other day. About 3,000 entries were made, half as many more than last year.

Returns of Manitoba crops have been made to Ottawa. They are said to indicate an increase.

The second batch of the Salvation army, has arrived at Ottawa.

Yesterday was the day on which the election was held. While it was said to have taken place, but it is uncertain.

Colonel Taylor, Winnipeg, met with an accident near Nepean, Dufferin county. He was thrown from the stage coach, and having his right leg fractured in two places above the knee. At last news came that he was recovering.

Hanlon has arrived in England, but hasn't refused to come back.

McCarthy has arrived in New York.

Serious lack has been prevailing in Southern Manitoba.
